column4: inferiorHuman:  i thought  gigabit can only be done by autonegotiation, but i might be wrong
you dont use davfs2 by any random weird strange out of this world chance, do you?
morning - hows your webdav doing?
use it from time to time, yes

Nautilus/.gvfs has a bug, where it absorbs the file you're uploading into RAM just prior to sending it to the server. Well, if you send big files, guess what, your RAM maxes out and the connection tanks.

so I looked at davfs2 which utilizes the sudo mount -t blah blah command, and I can get it working, but only as read only. So now I'm struggling to find how to use sudo mount -t davfs as read/write for a non root user.
hehe - just make a standard mount, automount at boot time... use nautilus on this mountpoint then
I'm trying to get it tow ork manually first, as I don't want my work laptop to consistently auto mount it. My desktop however, that's fine.
I figured I'd just create a bash script with the entire mount -t blah blah command in it so I can run, say, sudo ./webdav and connect manually
but it's all useless if everything is read only
http://nopaste.dk/p5552 - strangely the call does not return, but in another shell i can read and write - and things shwo up on oc
I just won the prize
what's funny is, when I right click, theres still options grayed out. create new folder is gryaed out. but if I click it... I create a new folder anyway....
you use a different way than me, i c
how different?
i mounted as a user witht he fusefs tool - there you don't need this user stuff. your way is nicer - if you are/have root
how is my wya nicer if I require root???
as you can put it in /etc/fstab and won'thave to worry about stuff anymore
I see. It struck me as being a little messy with having to have the file set, dir set, and user listed, but I suppose it works.
it'll be easy enough to put this in a bash script and call on the bash script when needed
good ;-)
I'm creating a 5GB bogus file now to send tot he server just as a test to see if it ramps up my memory instantly and maxes it out like nautilus did
its another implementation so i hope it'd work
